data.title: Do you have a favorite game composer?
data.meta_description:
I'll just list my top five composers(damn you, High Fidelity):

1) Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop, Wolf's Rain, Ghost in the Shell: SAC)
2) Yasunori Mitsuda...
data.text:
SuperPhillip

Resident Superhero

Joined

Dec 13, 2006

Messages

930

Location

Central City, MO

May 7, 2007

#1

I'll just list my top five composers(damn you, High Fidelity):

1) Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop, Wolf's Rain, Ghost in the Shell: SAC)

2) Yasunori Mitsuda (Chrono Trigger/Cross, Xenogears/saga, Graffiti Kingdom)

3) Nobuo Uematsu (Final Fantasy, Blue Dragon)

4) Kou Otani (Shadow of the Colossus, Gundam Wing, Outlaw Star)

5) Motoi Sakuraba (Star Ocean, Tales of Symphonia, Golden Sun)

You can discuss mine or name your own.

Lord Dalek

Uncreative Hack

Joined

Aug 17, 2003

Messages

40,602

Location

Dalek Empire

May 7, 2007

#2

1. Koji Kondo: easily the most famous and easily hummed composer in the world. DUH-DAH-DUH-DAH-DAH-DAH-Dooo

2. Hitoshi Sakimoto: My current favorite "rising star". Radiant Silvergun pulls off an amazing coup of being the most and least appropriate score for a shmup at the same time.

3. Yuzo Koshiro: Nobody knows how to use the Genesis sound hardware better him. Go Straight is still a classic.

4. The Konami Kukeiha Club: If you aren't dancing to Pleasure of Tension from Snatcher with 30 seconds, then you're a sad man.

5. Nobuo Uematsu: Yeah he's overrated. But who cares.

Koji Kondo would have to be, hands down, my favorite.

#8

Yay, my kind of thread! I could go all day with this...

-Koji Kondo: Much of the Mario series

-Yoshihiro Sakaguchi/Yoko Shimomura/Tatsuya Nishimura/Isao Abe: Street Fighter II

-Yuzo Koshiro: Super Adventure Island, Actraiser, Streets of Rage

-Mutato Muzika (Mark Mothersbaugh & Josh Mancell): Crash Bandicoot 1-Racing

-David Wise: Donkey Kong Country 1-3 (w/Evelyn Fischer and Robin Beanland), Diddy Kong Racing, Battletoads series, Marble Madness

-Nazo Suzuki: Dynamite Headdy

-Spiralmouth: Crash Twinsanity, Crash Tag Team Racing

-Masato Nakamura: Sonic 1 & 2

-Nathan McCree: Tomb Raider 1-3

-Richard Joseph: Putty, Putty Squad, James Pond

-Dan Forden: Mortal Kombat series

-Tim/Geoff Follin: Plok, Spiderman and the X-Men in Arcade's Revenge

-Howard Drossnin: Sonic 3/Knuckles

-Stewart Copeland: Spyro the Dragon series

-Shinobu Amayake: Stunt Race FX (a shame he didn't do more...)

-Harumi Ueko/Kazuhiko Uehara: TMNT 4: Turtles in Time, Batman Returns (with Jun Funahashi; one of the best soundtracks for the SNES), Tiny Toons: Wacky Sports Challenge (Jun Funahashi & M. Matsuhira)

-Mark Baril: Power Piggs of the Dark Age (don't laugh, this game has some good music)

-Gilles Leveille: Jersey Devil (MORE! Do more!)

-Hiroshi Kawaguchi: Outrun

-Kazunaka Yamane: Double Dragon 2, Super Double Dragon

-Setsuo Yamamoto/Makoto Tomozawa/Yuki Iwai/Yuko Takehara/Toshihiko Horiyama: Mega Man X

-Tommy Tallarico: Earthworm Jim 2, Aladdin, Cool Spot, MDK

-Yumiko Kameya/Naoto Ishida: F-Zero

-Raphael Gesqua: Mr. Nutz (again, don't laugh. There are some good tunes in here)

-Yuichi Sakakura/Tomoya Tomita/Kouzou Nakamura: TMNT 3: The Manhattan Project

-Tomomi Hatakeyama: Lemmings (SNES)

-Hirokazu Tanaka/Ryohji Yoshitomi/Kazumi Totaka: Mario Paint

-David Whittaker: Krusty's Super Fun House

-Matt Berardo: Bubsy

-Michael Bartlow: B.O.B.

-Brian Schmidt: Zoop (SNES)

-Brian Luzietti/Mitchell Stein: Clay Fighter

-Kyohei Sada/Inata/Ootera/Toyo: Spanky's Quest

-Mark Miller: Earthworm Jim, Taz-Mania (SNES) (w/Mitchell Stein, Mark Jason Anderson, John Schappert)

-Charlie Y.K/Hiya/Hiroshi: Super R-Type

-Rika Shigeno/Keiji Yamagishi/Kaori Nakabai/Hiroshi Miyazaki: Tecmo Super Bowl

-Hiroyuki Hamada: Tempo

-Steve Kirk: Voodoo Vince

There's also a buttload of games which don't have composers listed but have great music (mostly from the "NES and before" era), and to list all of those would take far too long.

PC!

#13

My answers are completely stock, but I promise I've thought them out.

Nobuo Uematsu composed the Final Fantasy VI soundtrack, which is by far my favorite game score of all time. For that, he's my favorite.

Koji Kondo is the definitive runner up for creating so many of the different themes I'm fond of. It was a huge treat to see him perform the Super Mario Bros. theme live on piano.
